p.s: The excerpt at hand dealing with Daisy and Gatsby's reunion after so many years is very crucial for an understanding of the complexity of GatsbysGatsby's characteristics.
The excerpt reveals Gatsby's character at its purest and most revealing, because he does not and also cannot put up and act, to the extent like he normally does.
Gatsby's characteristic stages can be divided into two stages, seperatedseparated by Nick leaving him and Daisy to themselves in his livingroom.
The first impression of Gatsby that you have in this excerpt, is that he seems to be extremlyextremely nervous and scared of the situation.
He is described to glare tragically into Nick's eyes (p. 84 ll. 16), which shows how helpless and scared he is in that situation.

The fact that he went out of the backdoor only to come in again as if he hasn't been waiting for Daisy the whole afternoon (see p. 84 ll. 13-15) implies how nervous he must be, but also shows again how absurdly desperaet he is to keep up a certain, unphased image of himself.
This is something which the whole excerpt really sheds light on the contrast between how he's presented in the previous chapters to this excerpt.
Normally Gatsby keeps up a fassadefacade, a certain image of himself, by his extremlyextremely careful self-presentation.
In this excerpt he is more vulnerable and real.

When first meeting Daisy, Gatsby tries to seem relaxed and not phased, as he puts his hands in his pocket in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease (ll. 27-28), which means that he tries so hard to seem relaxed, that it's clearly visible that he is in fact not relaxed, but very nervous and stressed.
His attempt at a laugh (p. 85) shows now he is trying to ease the awkwardness and the embarrassment of the situation, which does not work as well.

Afterwards he replies way too fast and explicit to DaisysDaisy's more rethoricrhetoric statement about how long they hadn't seen each other with the excatexact year and months (p. 85 ll. 15-17), which again shows how he is everything but relaxed and gives a hint to the literal obsession that he has with Daisy.
It becomes clear how insecure and miserable Gatsby really is in the situation, when he speaks to Nick with the expression Oh, God!, which shows that he knows that the situation is awkward.

He says that the reunion was a terrible mistake (p. 86 l. 1), the repititionrepetition of the word terrible underlines his own image here, that he doesn't even notice that Daisy clearly isn't relaxed as well (p. 86 ll. 5-6).
This talk of Gatsby and Nick marks a change in the excerpt.
Nick goes out to the gardens after that and when he comes up the situation seems to be drastically different.
The most striking features of the conversation before, the embarrasmentembarrassment and the awkwardness seem to have vanished (p. 87 ll. 10-11).
While Daisy has a teary face, Gatsby seems like he is completely changed.
While the first stage of him was characterized by insecurity, vulnerability and nervousness it is now the complete other way around.
Nick describes that a new wellbeing radiated from him (p. 87 ll. 15).
Gatsby seems as if he was reborn, like a new person - in a positive way.
He seems so changed, that Nick wouldn't have wondered if he reintroduced himself to him (p. 86 ll. 17).

You can see that Gatsby gained some of his self-control back by him using the expression old sport (p. 87 ll. 16) again, which he's always used in the previous chapters, but not in his nervousness before meeting Daisy.
Gatsby is so dazed and reliefedrelieved and happy, that he hasn't even noticed the change in the weather (see p. 87 ll. 18-19).
His smile has also come back (see p. 87 ll. 20), which effects Nick has discussed in previous chapters already.

But Gatsby hasn't forgotten about the image which he wants Daisy to have of him; he still wants to show off his wealth to impress her, so he invites both of them, Daisy and Nick, to his mansion to show them around (see p. 87 ll. 25-26), even though he knows, that Nick has been at his house before.
Looking at the narrative perspective, there are some interesting elements which contribute to the way Gatsby is characterized.
One of them is the use of the symbol of the weather throughout the excerpt.

It is interesting to see that when the situation between Daisy and Gatsby is still awkward by and he is still in his first stage, there are many descriptions of the rainy weather (see p. 86 ll. 16, p. 84 ll. 14-15).
When the situation has changed and Gatsby is in his second stage of positive feelings, the weather has changed without him noticing, now the room is full of sunshine (see p. 87 ll. 20).
Another narrative technique that was used in chapter two as well, is Nick just leaving out parts of situations by either just not mentioning them or as in this excerpt, leaving the scene.
So when the first person narrator leaves the scene, you obviously can't know what is happening in the time away.
This is what Nick did when he went out (see p. 86 ll. 13).
We can only imagine what Gatsby and Daisy talked about and what led to her crying and his drastic change in character.
The fact that Gatsby is described more and that Nick talks to him more than to Daisy, so we know more of his thoughts is important for our impression of Gatsby as well.
Daisy could have seemed way more nervous, if Nick had talked to her more are described her more.
Nick also describes how Gatsby almost destroys a clock (see p. 85 ll. 5-8) which has very symbolic meaning of trying to turn back time for him and Daisy.
The setting is also crucial in this scene looking at Gatsby.
We know from the previous chapters that in his mansion, amongst all of his expensive things, Gatsby feels secure and untouchable.
His normal surroundings are a constant reminder, that he made it and that all of his wealth stands for him.
In the setting in the excerpt though he has to stand for himself.
As it takes place in Nick's living room, which looks rather basic, the only thing that can make an impression is himself and his character.

That makes him even more nervous, which is why he really wants Daisy to come over to his house to see him in all of his glory and wealth and to prove to her that he has become the very thing, that she wanted him to all these years ago.
In conclusion you can see that in this chapter one can finally get to know the real Gatsby, not only his fassadefacade.
It shows, that behind all of his wealth, he is a very vulnerable and insecure person, who desperatlydesperately wants validation from Daisy.
Both presented sides of Gatsby the negative and positive feelings are the first real and not controlled or calculated actions of him.
The reunion with Daisy is so significant, that he loses his most important feautrefeature, his extreme self-control.
